description: From Middle English witnesse, from Old English ġewitnes, equivalent to wit +‎ -ness. Cognate with Middle Dutch wetenisse (“witness, testimony”), Old High German gewiznessi (“testimony”), literary German gewissen (“to witness”), Icelandic vitni (“witness”).

entries.meaning: (uncountable) Attestation of a fact or event; testimony.
examples: She can bear witness, since she was there at the time.

entries.meaning: (countable) One who sees or has personal knowledge of something.
examples: As a witness to the event, I can confirm that he really said that.

entries.meaning: (countable, law) Someone called to give evidence in a court.
examples: The witness for the prosecution did not seem very credible.

entries.meaning: (countable) One who is called upon to witness an event or action, such as a wedding or the signing of a document.
examples: The bridesmaid and best man at a wedding typically serve as the witnesses.

entries.meaning: (countable) Something that serves as evidence; a sign or token.

verbs.description: witness (third-person singular simple present witnesses, present participle witnessing, simple past and past participle witnessed)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To furnish proof of, to show.
examples: This certificate witnesses his presence on that day.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To see or gain knowledge of through experience.
(intransitive, construed with to or for) To present personal religious testimony; to preach at (someone) or on behalf of.
To see the execution of (a legal instrument), and subscribe it for the purpose of establishing its authenticity.
examples: to witness a bond or a deed
